```{r warning = FALSE, message=FALSE}
library(readr)

lego <- read_csv("../lecture2/lego.csv")

head(lego)
```

```{r}
# Use plot() to make scatter plots
plot(Amazon_Price~Pieces, lego)
# plot([y-variable]~[x-variable], dataframe)
```
```{r}
# This step creates a new dataset of lego sets with less than 2000 pieces, so data is more clustered
lego_under_2k_pieces <- subset(lego, Pieces < 2000)
```

```{r}
# Plotting data set with lego sets with less than 2000 pieces 
plot(Amazon_Price~Pieces, lego_under_2k_pieces)
```

```{r}
# Use lm() to fit linear models of prices versus pieces
# The ~ here separates the response and explanatory variables.
lm(Amazon_Price~Pieces, lego_under_2k_pieces)
```

```{r}
# we can save a fit into mod1, 
mod1 = lm(Amazon_Price~Pieces, lego_under_2k_pieces)
plot(Amazon_Price~Pieces, data=lego_under_2k_pieces)
abline(mod1)
```

```{r}
# mod1 contains many useful objects.Use $ to extract them.
# mod1$residuals extracts residuals of the fit.
# mod1$fitted.values extracts the predictions of the response.

summary(mod1)
```

```{r}
head(mod1$residuals)
head(mod1$fitted.values)
```

```{r}
plot(mod1$residuals~mod1$fitted.values)
abline(0,0)
hist(mod1$residuals, breaks = 200)
qqnorm(mod1$residuals)
qqline(mod1$residuals)
```

```{r}
#Sets randomization
set.seed(455001)
#Sample of 99 values from a Normal distribution; mean=0; sd=1; sorted ascending
x = sort(rnorm(99, 0, 1))
hist(x)
#list of integers 1 through 99.
y = c(1:99)

#z-scores of dataset of 99 values if perfectly normally distributed
#the z-score calculated relates to the percent of the data if taking the area of the left tail
normy = qnorm(y/100)
plot(x~normy)
qqline(x)
```

# Finding a dataset of lego sets with pieces under 1100
lego_under_1100_pieces <- subset(lego, lego$Pieces < 1100)

mod2 = lm(Amazon_Price~Pieces, data = lego_under_1100_pieces)
